newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ non-housing borrowing down in Sept qtr - Westpac.
newsitem.headline: NZ non-housing borrowing down in Sept qtr - Westpac.

text.p: New Zealand consumer borrowing for non-housing related purposes fell in the September quarter for the first time in two years, according to the latest Westpac FPG household savings indicators.

Westpac Financial Services Chief Investment Officer David Beattie said borrowing for purposes other than buying a house fell by one percent or NZ$80 million in the quarter, having previously been growing steadily at around $200 million per quarter since December 1994.
Housing-related borrowing rose by only $760 million, whereas it had previously been rising at around $1.4 billion.
Deposits held at financial institutions were relatively unchanged.

"It would appear as though there has been an element of debt repayment occurring in the September quarter," Beattie said, adding that total deposits had previously been rising at a rate of around $1 billion per quarter.
He said it was too early to conclude that New Zealanders had made a permanent shift in savings patterns, but the signs were encouraging.

Lower consumer borrowing could, however, mean households were trying to cut debt after a spending surge before tax cuts that took effect last July. If so, higher consumer borrowing could resume in the December quarter, Beattie said.
The overall net worth of New Zealanders fell 0.9 percent in the September quarter, largely because of a 0.6 percent fall in house prices over the same period.
